by a fragment of the former. Enough of the pterygoid remains 
to demonstrate its ovine <s>and caprine<\s> affinities in the 
<s>small<\s> wide angle it makes with the basi- and presphenoid. 
The heighth of the foramen magnum 1.22 is the same as 
its breadth. On the occiput the nuchal space is well 
seen and the two impressions for the cervical muscles 
are very deep. The occipital ridge above hem is broken away. 
the occipito-parietal suture is very well shown on the coronal 
surface. The spongy bases of the horncores do not extend as 
far back as the occiput and are separated from one another 
in the middle by 0.65 inches. The horncores themselves 
agree exactly with those of the recent animal and 
their description therefore would be superfluous. <s>a<\s>At a 
distance of e<s>eighteen<\s> 1.8 inches from the horncores a ridge runs 
across the frontals from the roof of one orbit to the other 
it is much more pronounced thn in any of the skulls 
of the existing Musk Sheep. A reference in the Table of 
Skull measurements will show how vastly <s>their<\s> this skull 
surpasses in size any of those which are recorded of the 
living or fossil animal. The <s>following section shows the<\s> 
exact position in which <s>the head<\s> it was found is shown by 
the following section, taken on the north side of an old 
working and not very far from the superintendents office 
(Insert section 2) 
This section agrees essentially with that taken at some 
distance off and published in my paper on the Lower 
Brickearths of the Thames Valley, X with the exception that 
in this the ferruginous gravel bed (No 5) has thinned out. No 4
